header.title: Reiki Shamanism: A Guide to Out-of-Body Healing
header.category: Western Esotericism, Energy Healing, Shamanism, Reiki, Occultism

central_thesis: The central thesis asserts that Reiki, despite its Western interpretations, is fundamentally a shamanic practice rooted in ancient traditions, including Buddhist and Native American spiritual ways. By integrating Reiki's energy channeling (Ki) via symbols and attunements with shamanic journeying into non-ordinary reality, practitioners can achieve higher spiritual insight and facilitate 'out-of-body healing' for themselves, others, and the Earth. The book positions the 'Reiki Shaman' as a facilitator of universal life force to restore wholeness and balance across all aspects of existence, emphasizing that the marriage of these modalities creates a healing effect greater than either practiced separately.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the author's personal discovery of combining Reiki with shamanic journeying, arguing for Reiki's inherent shamanic nature. It sets the stage for the book as the fourth in a series on environmental shamanism, demonstrating how Eastern Reiki traditions can be integrated into a shamanic framework for profound healing.

This chapter explores diverse concepts of the energy body, detailing the Westernized seven-chakra system, its historical evolution, and alternative chakra models (e.g., 13-chakra, 22-chakra systems, musical scale correspondences). It delves into scientific measurements of bodily frequencies and brainwave patterns (Beta, Alpha, Theta, Delta) in relation to meditation and shamanic drumming, and discusses the symbolic significance of chakra colors and the 'body as oscillator' concept.

This chapter historically and philosophically argues that Reiki's origins are deeply shamanic, tracing Dr. Mikao Usui's practices—such as mountaintop fasting and vision quests leading to the discovery of symbols—to indigenous traditions like Tibetan Bön and Native American spiritual paths. It defines Rei-Ki as 'Guided Life-Force Energy,' a spiritual (shinrei ryoho) rather than religious (shinko ryoho) method. It introduces the main Usui Reiki symbols (Cho ku Rei, Sei he ki, Hon sha ze sho nen, Dai Ko Myo) and the author's 'PathFinder Symbols' (Problem Solver, Stillpoint, Threshold/Ascension), explaining their uses, and describes typical Reiki attunements and treatments.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Three: Healing Through The Shamanic Journey
structure_content.summary: This chapter establishes shamanism as the most ancient extant healing technology, highlighting its use of non-drug induced altered states of consciousness, primarily through rhythmic drumming. It explains 'nonordinary reality' as the 'really real' world, accessible through dreaming and shamanic journeying, which transcends physical limitations. It outlines the cosmology of the 'lower, middle, and upper worlds' within shamanic practice and describes four fundamental methods of energy work: channeling, reflecting, taking on, and melding.

This chapter provides practical applications and personal anecdotes illustrating the combined use of Reiki and shamanism, focusing on advanced techniques such as distance healing, soul retrieval, and psychopomp work (guiding souls to the afterlife). It addresses ethical considerations like obtaining permission for healing and emphasizes the role of power animals. A significant portion is dedicated to the integration of natural quartz crystals as powerful energy magnifiers and transmuters in healing practices. The chapter also briefly overviews other energy modalities like Therapeutic Touch, Aromatherapy, Homeopathy, and Flower Essences, contextualizing Reiki Shamanism within a broader spectrum of alternative energy medicine.

key_concepts.definition: A Japanese form of energy medicine involving sacred symbols and guides; use of the hands to channel healing energy. The author reinterprets its origins as shamanic.

A Siberian word meaning 'one who sees in the dark'; a person who uses earth energy, guides, and power animals for insight. The author asserts that Reiki's origins are shamanic, and its practices align with traditional shamanic techniques.

A non-physical body extending twenty-seven feet in all directions, continuing into other dimensions. It can appear as a 'luminous egg,' a 'star tetrahedron,' or a layering of energetic shapes. It is the basis for out-of-body healing.

Sanskrit for 'circle or wheel,' these are energetic centers in the core of the body linked by a central psychic energy channel. The book discusses various chakra systems (7, 13, 22) and their corresponding colors, musical notes, and measurable frequencies, emphasizing their Western historical reinterpretation.

Universal life-force energy, inherent in all beings and omnipresent. In Reiki, 'Rei' signifies mystery/spirit, making Rei-Ki 'Guided Life-Force Energy' that has wisdom and is channeled for healing. It is the key to Reiki practice and self-healing.

What is 'really real,' distinct from our consensus reality (tonal); reality as perceived when everyday constraints and predispositions are eliminated through trance, shamanic journeying, or other methods. It is the realm where healing and spiritual insights occur.

A natural, non-drug induced altered state of consciousness, typically achieved through rhythmic drumming (4-7 cycles per second, activating Theta waves), allowing a practitioner to travel to the 'lower, middle, or upper worlds' for healing, knowledge, and interaction with spirit guides and power animals.
An animal (or 'totem') that offers guidance and protection during shamanic journeys and in daily life. Individuals are born with at least one, and it serves as a guide in nonordinary reality.
An inner place of total silence and stillness, serving as the origin of intuition, creativity, and balance. It is achieved by quieting internal dialogue and focusing inward.

Unique symbols discovered by the author in Dreamtime, including: 'Problem Solver' (simplifies complex issues), 'Stillpoint' (balance, centeredness, doorway), and 'Threshold/Ascension' (representing beginning/end and completion/passing through). These can be used by anyone, even without attunement, for subtle energetic work.

A shamanic healing technique involving journeying to retrieve fragmented soul parts or essences lost due to trauma or stolen by others. These parts are then returned to the client's energy body for wholeness.
The practice of helping souls transition into the afterlife, often performed during shamanic journeys, particularly in cases of sudden death or mass tragedies.

In sacred geometry, a star tetrahedron representing an energetic framework or blueprint for spirit. It includes the light body and is considered the vehicle for consciousness to journey through different dimensions, transcending time and space.

Natural quartz crystals (SiO2) used as powerful energy magnifiers, transmuters, filters, and generators due to their piezoelectric properties and highly ordered atomic structures. They are integrated into practice to amplify intent, balance energy fields, and assist in healing and divination.

practical_system.description: The practical system presented is 'Reiki Shamanism,' a synthesized modality for healing self, others, and the Earth through the conscious direction of universal life force (Ki) by integrating Reiki techniques with shamanic journeying. It operates on the premise that the human 'energy body' (Merkaba) extends beyond the physical into multi-dimensional 'nonordinary reality.' The practitioner, acting as a 'hollow bone,' channels divine energy, guided by spirit allies, to address dis-ease (e.g., spiritual intrusions, soul loss) by restoring balance and harmony. This includes in-person and long-distance healing, soul retrieval, and psychopomp work, emphasizing discernment, humility, and the ethical principle of obtaining permission for healing interventions.
tools: Drum/Rattle: Primary instruments for inducing Theta brainwave states necessary for shamanic journeying.

Usui Reiki Symbols: Cho ku Rei (power), Sei he ki (mental/emotional), Hon sha ze sho nen (distance healing/time transcendence), Dai Ko Myo (master/life purpose), used for various energetic applications.
PathFinder Reiki Symbols (author's own): Problem Solver (simplifies issues), Stillpoint (balance, doorway), Threshold/Ascension (beginning/end, completion), usable via drawing or intent.

Natural Quartz Crystals: Used as energy magnifiers, transmuters, and filters; incorporated into medicine circles, held during journeys, or placed in environments for healing, grounding, and protection. Selection is often intuitive.
Stuffed Cloth Figures: Used as proxies for clients during long-distance healing sessions, serving as a focal point for energetic work.
Healing Bowl of Water: Employed to neutralize and dissipate negative energies or spiritual intrusions removed during healing work.
Personal Crystal (for journeys): A specific crystal held during shamanic journeys to aid focus and amplify energetic connection.
Notebook/Journal: For meticulously recording visions, insights, and experiences from shamanic journeys and Dreamtime for later analysis and understanding.
Smudge Sticks / Liquid Smudge: For energetic purification of spaces and individuals.
rituals: Reiki Attunements: A Reiki Master implants sacred symbols into the student's crown and palm chakras to activate and enhance their ability to channel Ki.

Reiki Treatments: Practitioners use specific hand placements (on or near the body) to transmit, guide, and focus healing energy, break energetic blockages, and remove spiritual intrusions, often employing Reiki symbols with intent. Can be applied in-person or long-distance via proxies.

Shamanic Journeying: Entering a non-ordinary state of consciousness (Theta brainwaves, 4-7 Hz) typically induced by rhythmic drumming or rattling (approx. 70 bpm). This allows travel to the 'lower, middle, and upper worlds' to interact with power animals and spirit guides for knowledge, healing, and addressing imbalances.

Soul Retrieval: A shamanic journey to locate and retrieve lost 'soul parts' (essence or energetic fragments) resulting from trauma. The retrieved part is symbolically blown into the client's heart and crown chakras, followed by Reiki symbols to seal and integrate it.
Psychopomp Work: Guiding disoriented souls of the deceased towards the light or afterlife, often performed in nonordinary reality following significant events like accidents or tragedies.

Smudging: Burning sacred plants (e.g., sage, cedar, sweetgrass) or using liquid herbal essences to energetically cleanse an area, purify individuals, and raise the vibrational rate before and during healing ceremonies.

Prayer and Intent with Discernment: Consciously directing intent with humility, asking for divine assistance rather than imposing personal will, allowing universal 'Creator's Power' to facilitate healing while detaching from specific outcomes.
Permission Protocol: Strictly obtaining permission from the client or their higher self before performing any healing work, recognizing it as a universal spiritual law and ethical prerequisite.

“Reiki itself is a form of shamanism; there really is no separation between them.’ From his heart he shares what our ancestors have lived since the beginning of time; to be one with our Mother Earth and to heal each other."

The Creator made each and every one of us this way. We must only realize our uniqueness — and what we share: infinite being. At its center, each one of us.”

Reihou or spiritual method, Reiki method, he founded: Shaman Who Makes Rain.

The great wonder of Reiki when combined with shamanism is that one does not have to ‘go to the mountain’ to reach its full benefits of visioning, healing and self-discovery; through the magic of the shamanic journey, the mountain comes to you! The experience of the glimpse or kensho of satori (deep, or lasting enlightenment) that Dr. Usui discovered on the fast is given to anyone who learns how to journey and accepts the attunements. It is a beautiful gift for all humankind.

The essence of protecting yourself from psychic attacks is to not be duped into believing that you are vulnerable; you are not. If encountered, brujos, sorcerers, or any malignant entities might attempt to trick you into believing you are already vulnerable or under their control or harmed by them. If you believe it, then you have given them your power and opened the door for further attacks. With your power animals and Creator’s Power, you are invulnerable.
“Shape your world through your light. Illuminate your unique path. Don’t live in the shadow of others’ judgments. They are not yours — unless you let them be so.”

critical_analysis.relevance: From an esoteric and occult perspective, 'Reiki Shamanism' is highly relevant for its syncretic approach to spiritual healing, explicitly bridging modern energy work with ancient magical traditions. The author's reinterpretation of Reiki's origins as shamanic aligns with a broader trend in Western Esotericism to uncover universal principles underlying diverse practices, such as the Hermetic concept of 'as above, so below' applied to the energetic body and dimensions. The detailed explanation of shamanic journeying into 'nonordinary reality' and working with spirit guides resonates strongly with astral projection, spirit communication, and animistic magic found in grimoire traditions and modern Chaos Magic, where the practitioner navigates inner and outer planes of existence. The book's embrace of a scientific framework (vibrational frequencies, brainwave states) to explain esoteric phenomena positions it within the 'science and magic' dialogue prevalent in modern occultism, seeking to demystify spiritual experiences through systematic understanding. The development of 'PathFinder Symbols' by the author, alongside traditional Reiki symbols, exemplifies the personalized grimoire tradition, where practitioners create and adapt magical tools to their evolving systems. The emphasis on discernment and ethical considerations in energy work, particularly regarding permission and the 'hollow bone' principle, reinforces core ethical tenets found across various magical currents, distinguishing operative magic from ego-driven manipulation. The comparative analysis with Buddhist and Native American traditions enriches the understanding of cross-cultural magical currents.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for 'Reiki Shamanism' includes practitioners and students of both Reiki and shamanism, as well as individuals interested in holistic healing, energy medicine, and personal spiritual development. It caters to those seeking to deepen their existing practices by integrating the two modalities for enhanced healing effects, particularly in 'out-of-body' or 'long-distance' contexts. The book is also suitable for spiritual seekers curious about indigenous wisdom, altered states of consciousness, and the energetic structure of reality, offering practical exercises for self-discovery and a comprehensive glossary for understanding key concepts. Its accessible style, while providing technical depth, makes it appealing to both beginners and more experienced practitioners looking for a structured system of combined energy work.
